content.text: To maintain Eduversal Partner Schools' status as approved Cambridge Assessment International Education Centres, ensure examination integrity, deliver high-quality Cambridge curriculum and assessments, and comply with all Cambridge policies and procedures.

content.title: What is a Cambridge Centre?
content.text: A Cambridge Centre is a school or institution approved by Cambridge Assessment International Education to deliver Cambridge curriculum, register students for exams, administer exams under secure conditions, and receive official certificates and results. Each Centre holds a unique Centre number (e.g., ID### for Indonesian centres).

content.title: Centre Registration Process
items: Eligibility Assessment: Valid Indonesian license, adequate facilities, qualified staff, commitment to Cambridge standards
Application Submission: Complete Centre application via Cambridge International Direct, nominate key roles, pay application fee
Cambridge Review: Application review and possible site visit (4-8 weeks)
Centre Approval: Receive Centre number and login credentials, status valid indefinitely subject to compliance

content.title: Annual Centre Declaration
content.text: Every year, each Centre must submit an Annual Centre Declaration confirming current contact details, key personnel updates, adequate facilities, and commitment to Cambridge standards. Declaration typically sent February-March, deadline before exam entries open. Non-submission may result in suspension of Centre status.

content.title: Evidence
items: Cambridge Centre number certificate
Annual declaration submissions (past 3 years)
Correspondence with Cambridge regarding Centre status

content.text: Cambridge requires each Centre to designate specific individuals responsible for examination integrity and quality assurance.

content.title: Centre Head
resp: Overall accountability for Cambridge Centre compliance
Ensure secure exam administration and prevent malpractice
Approve student registrations and exam entries
Sign off on examination results and irregularities
Liaise with Cambridge regarding Centre matters
Ensure staff understand and follow Cambridge policies

content.title: Exams Officer
content.note: Dedicated staff member (Admin Manager, Vice Principal, or senior teacher)

tasks: Coordinate exam entries (registration, subject selection, tier decisions)
Submit entries to Cambridge by deadlines
Schedule exam timetable and resolve clashes
Arrange exam rooms, seating plans, invigilation schedules
Train invigilators on Cambridge exam conduct rules
Communicate exam schedules to students and parents
Oversee secure storage of exam materials
Distribute exam papers to invigilators at Key Times
Monitor exam conduct and respond to irregularities
Collect completed scripts and secure until dispatch
Package and dispatch scripts to Cambridge within 2 days
Submit attendance registers and incident reports
Communicate results to students when released
Manage post-results services (EARs, access to scripts, appeals)

content.title: Quality Nominee
content.note: Senior academic leader (Principal, Vice Principal Academic, or HOD)
resp: Monitor teaching quality and curriculum coverage against Cambridge standards
Review student work and assessment practices for alignment
Identify professional development needs for Cambridge delivery
Liaise with Cambridge on curriculum updates and resources
Participate in Cambridge training and quality assurance initiatives

content.text: Eduversal Partner Schools deliver the Cambridge curriculum across multiple stages, tailored to student age and progression.

content.title: Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS)
content.text: Play-based learning framework for ages 0-5 with seven areas of learning and development. Not formally assessed by Cambridge but provides foundation for Primary.

content.title: Cambridge Primary (Ages 5-11)
content.text: Subjects: English, Mathematics, Science. Skills-based approach with clear learning objectives emphasizing inquiry and problem-solving. Optional Cambridge Primary Checkpoint tests at end (Grade 6, age 11) provide diagnostic feedback comparing performance to international benchmarks.

content.title: Cambridge Lower Secondary (Ages 11-14)
content.text: Core subjects: English, Mathematics, Science. Additional subjects may include ICT, Global Perspectives, Art, Music, PE. Builds on Primary and deepens conceptual understanding. Optional Checkpoint at end (Grade 9, age 14) provides readiness assessment for IGCSE.

content.title: Cambridge IGCSE (Ages 14-16, Grades 10-11)
content.text: International General Certificate of Secondary Education recognized globally as equivalent to national secondary qualifications. Wide range of 70+ subjects available. Students typically take 5-10 IGCSEs over two years. Assessment primarily through external exams at end of course, with some subjects including coursework.

content.title: Typical IGCSE Subject Offering
rows: English ESL/Literature, Mathematics (Core/Extended), Sciences (Biology, Chemistry, Physics)
Art & Design, ICT, Computer Science, Design & Technology

content.title: Cambridge AS & A Level (Ages 16-18, Grades 11-13)
content.text: Advanced Subsidiary (AS) Level: One-year course, typically 3-4 subjects. A Level: Two-year course, depth and rigor comparable to first-year university. Widely recognized for university admission globally including UK, Australia, Canada, US, Europe, and increasingly competitive Indonesian universities.

content.title: AS/A Level Grading
rows: Grades a, b, c, d, e (lowercase)
Grades A* (highest), A, B, C, D, E, U (ungraded)

content.text: Cambridge offers two main examination series per year. Eduversal Partner Schools typically use both series depending on student needs.

content.title: May/June Series (Primary Series)
content.text: Exam Period: Late April to Early June. Results Release: Early-Mid August. Typical students: Grade 10 (IGCSE), Grade 11 (AS Level), Grade 12 (A Level).

content.title: October/November Series (Supplementary)
content.text: Exam Period: Late October to Late November. Results Release: Mid-January. Typical students: Retaking exams to improve grades, missed May/June due to illness, or students on accelerated/deferred timelines.

content.title: Cambridge Primary & Lower Secondary Checkpoint
content.text: Schools may administer Checkpoint tests during October/November or May/June windows. Tests administered by school staff (not invigilated like IGCSE/AS/A). Scripts sent to Cambridge for marking. Results typically returned 2-3 months after test window.
Responsibility: Exams Officer in coordination with Principal/GM, Academic Coordinators, and students/parents.

content.title: Step 1: Student Subject Selection (Term before exams)
items: Academic counseling sessions review student strengths, interests, and university plans
Explain subject requirements, combinations, and tier options (e.g., Mathematics Extended vs Core)
Students select 5-10 subjects from school's offerings
Principal/Academic Coordinator approves based on prerequisites, timetable feasibility, and teacher capacity
Finalize subject list by end of Term 1 (October-November)

content.title: Step 2: Exam Entries Submission (8-10 weeks before exams)
items: Exams Officer accesses Cambridge International Direct portal
Enter student details: name (as per passport/ID), date of birth, candidate number, subjects, syllabus codes, tier, components
Request access arrangements for students with documented learning needs (must be pre-approved)
Exams Officer reviews entries for accuracy, Centre Head approves submission
Submit by deadline (late submission incurs fees or may prevent registration)
Cambridge issues Entry Confirmation Report - verify all students and subjects correct
Communicate exam timetable and fees to students and parents

content.title: Step 3: Timetable Preparation (6-8 weeks before exams)
items: Cambridge issues Final Timetable showing date and time for each exam paper
Identify timetable clashes: students with two exams at same time
Resolution: One exam at scheduled time, second exam in 'clash session' later same day
Exams Officer creates School Exam Timetable with rooms, seating plans, invigilation assignments
Communicate to students (exam dates, times, room assignments) and staff (invigilation duties)

content.title: Entry Fees
items: Cambridge charges per subject per student
Fees vary by qualification (IGCSE, AS, A Level) and subject
School typically passes costs to students/parents (included in annual fees or billed separately)

subsections.title: Secure Storage and Exam Materials Management

content.text: Cambridge requires strict security protocols for all examination materials from receipt until dispatch. Responsibility: Exams Officer and Centre Head.

content.title: Secure Storage Requirements
items: Lockable metal cabinet or safe in a secure room with restricted access
Only Exams Officer and Centre Head hold keys
Access log maintained for all entries to storage area
CCTV coverage recommended but not mandatory
Temperature-controlled environment to prevent material degradation
Fire-resistant storage preferred
Room locked when unattended, even briefly

content.title: Key Times
content.text: Key Times are the specific date and time when exam papers may be opened. Printed on each exam packet. Centres MUST NOT open packets before Key Time under any circumstances (except for access arrangement verification). Violation constitutes malpractice and may result in Centre suspension.

content.title: Exam Materials Receipt and Verification
items: Secure materials typically arrive 3-4 weeks before exam series begins
Exams Officer signs for delivery and verifies package integrity (seals intact, no damage)
Check delivery note against timetable: verify all expected packets received
Store immediately in secure cabinet - do NOT leave unattended
Report any discrepancies (missing packets, damaged seals) to Cambridge within 24 hours
Maintain Materials Receipt Log with date, packet codes, condition notes

content.title: Pre-Exam Distribution (Key Time Adherence)
items: On exam day, Exams Officer retrieves relevant packets from secure storage maximum 1 hour before Key Time
Verify packet codes match exam timetable and attendance register
Open packets ONLY at Key Time in presence of another authorized staff member
Count question papers to match expected candidate numbers plus spares
Distribute papers to exam rooms: invigilators receive papers no more than 15 minutes before exam start
Unused/spare papers returned to secure storage immediately after distribution

content.title: During Exam: Secure Handling
items: All exam materials (question papers, answer booklets, scripts) remain under invigilation at all times
Students not permitted to remove ANY exam materials from room (including question papers after exam ends)
If student requires bathroom break, their script secured by invigilator until return
No photocopying or photography of exam materials permitted under any circumstances

content.title: Post-Exam: Script Collection and Storage
items: Invigilators collect scripts in candidate number order and place in secure envelope
Exams Officer verifies script count matches attendance register
Sealed scripts stored in secure cabinet until dispatch (usually within 2 days of exam)
Unused exam papers and materials secured separately (retained for 5 years per Cambridge policy)
Report any missing scripts or irregularities to Cambridge immediately

content.title: Confidential Waste Disposal
content.text: After exam series concludes and all results released, destroy unused exam papers and surplus materials by shredding or secure disposal. DO NOT discard intact papers in regular trash. Maintain disposal log for audit purposes.
Proper invigilation ensures examination integrity, fairness, and compliance with Cambridge regulations. All invigilators must be trained annually on Cambridge exam conduct rules.

content.title: Invigilator Qualifications and Selection
items: Must be adults (18+) with no conflict of interest (not relatives of candidates, not teaching the subject being examined)
Fluent in English to understand instructions and communicate with students
Reliable, professional, and capable of maintaining discipline
Teachers from the school may invigilate subjects they do NOT teach
External invigilators (from partner schools or community) acceptable and often preferred for high-stakes exams
All invigilators complete annual training on Cambridge rules, emergency procedures, and malpractice detection

content.title: Exam Room Setup (Completed day before exam)
items: Desks arranged with minimum 1.25 meters between candidates in all directions
Each desk clearly labeled with candidate number (visible to invigilators)
Seating plan posted outside exam room
Wall clocks visible to all candidates (checked for accuracy)
Remove or cover all posters, maps, charts containing subject-related information
Display 'EXAM IN PROGRESS - SILENCE' signs outside room
Ensure adequate lighting, ventilation, and temperature control
Prepare candidate materials: pens (black/blue), pencils, rulers, calculators (if permitted), clean rough paper

content.title: Pre-Exam Procedures (30 minutes before start)
items: Invigilators arrive, receive exam materials, attendance register, seating plan from Exams Officer
Review Instructions for Conducting Examinations (ICE booklet) and note any special arrangements (access arrangements for specific students)
Greet candidates as they arrive, verify identity (student ID card, photo), direct to assigned seats
Candidates leave bags, phones, smartwatches, unauthorized materials in designated area outside room
Remind: only allowed materials on desk (pens, pencil case, water bottle with label removed, calculator if specified)
Candidates seated 10 minutes before start time

content.title: Exam Start Procedure (At Key Time)
items: Announce: 'You have [X hours/minutes] for this examination. The exam will end at [time].'
Announce: 'Read the instructions on the front of the exam paper carefully before you begin.'
Announce: 'You may not ask questions once the exam has started unless there is a misprint.'
Distribute exam papers FACE DOWN to each candidate
At exact start time: 'You may turn over your papers and begin.'
Start timing and note start time on board
Complete attendance register, marking absent candidates

content.title: During Exam: Invigilator Duties
items: Remain vigilant and move quietly around the room at irregular intervals
Monitor for malpractice: copying, use of unauthorized materials, phones, communication between candidates
Respond to candidate questions ONLY about misprints or defective papers (do NOT explain questions or provide hints)
If candidate requires bathroom, accompany or assign escort; candidate's script secured during absence
Announce time warnings: '15 minutes remaining,' '5 minutes remaining,' '1 minute remaining'
Maintain silence: no talking, reading, phone use by invigilators
Handle emergencies: medical issues, fire alarm, disturbances (follow Centre emergency procedures)

content.title: Exam Conclusion (End Time)
items: Announce: 'The exam has ended. Stop writing immediately and put your pens down.'
Announce: 'Remain seated silently while we collect your papers.'
Collect scripts in candidate number order (check each script has candidate details and number)
Count scripts and verify total matches attendance register
Announce: 'You may now leave quietly.'
Return scripts and attendance register to Exams Officer immediately; report any irregularities

content.title: Handling Malpractice During Exam
items: If malpractice suspected (copying, unauthorized materials), discreetly confiscate evidence
Allow candidate to complete exam under increased supervision
Complete Malpractice Report Form immediately after exam with specific details
Do NOT inform candidate of report during exam (to avoid distress/disruption)
Exams Officer submits report to Cambridge within 7 days

content.title: Prohibited Items in Exam Room
items: Mobile phones, smartwatches, fitness trackers (even if turned off)
Programmable calculators or calculators with text storage (unless specifically permitted)
Dictionaries (unless specified in syllabus, e.g., certain language exams)
Notes, textbooks, revision cards, formula sheets (except Cambridge-issued data sheets)
Food (except water in clear bottle with label removed, medical necessities with prior approval)

content.text: Cambridge provides two mechanisms to support candidates with additional needs or who experience adverse circumstances: Access Arrangements (pre-approved accommodations) and Special Considerations (post-exam adjustments).

content.title: Access Arrangements (Pre-Exam Accommodations)
content.text: Modifications to standard exam conditions for candidates with documented disabilities or learning differences (dyslexia, ADHD, visual/hearing impairment, physical disabilities). Arrangements ensure candidates can demonstrate knowledge without disadvantage due to their condition. MUST be applied for before exam entries deadline.

content.title: Common Access Arrangements
rows: Typically 25% additional (e.g., 3-hour exam becomes 3h 45m). Requires educational psychologist report.
Adult reads questions aloud or writes candidate's dictated answers. Used for severe dyslexia or physical disabilities.
Candidate takes exam alone or in small group to minimize distraction (ADHD, anxiety).
5-10 minute breaks without extra time. For medical conditions requiring movement/medication.
Braille, large print, or colored paper. Requires advance notice to Cambridge for printing.
Laptop/computer for typing responses (spelling/grammar check disabled). Screen reader software.

content.title: Applying for Access Arrangements
items: School Counselor/SENCO identifies students with documented needs (psychological/medical reports required)
Submit Access Arrangements Application via Cambridge International Direct portal minimum 3 months before exam
Include: candidate details, nature of disability, requested arrangement, supporting evidence (reports dated within 24 months)
Cambridge reviews and approves (typically 2-3 weeks). Centre receives confirmation and implementation guidelines
Exams Officer coordinates logistics: separate room, additional invigilators, modified materials
Arrangements valid for duration of course (e.g., approved for Year 10 IGCSE applies through Year 11)
Annual review required if circumstances change

content.title: Special Considerations (Post-Exam Adjustments)
content.text: Applied AFTER exam for candidates whose performance affected by circumstances beyond their control and not covered by pre-approved access arrangements. Results in potential small grade adjustment (typically 1-5% mark increase, rarely more). Does NOT guarantee grade improvement; depends on impact severity.

content.title: Grounds for Special Consideration
rows: Candidate unwell on exam day (fever, migraine, injury) but insisted on taking exam. Requires medical certificate.
Death of immediate family member (parent, sibling, grandparent) shortly before or during exams.
Fire alarm, construction noise, extreme weather, power outage during exam affecting concentration.
Family emergency, natural disaster, accident affecting candidate's preparation or exam day focus.
Centre error (wrong paper distributed, timing error) disadvantaging candidate.

content.title: Submitting Special Consideration
items: Centre Head makes decision whether circumstances warrant application (not automatic upon request)
Submit within 7 days of exam via Cambridge International Direct
Include: candidate details, exam affected, detailed explanation, supporting evidence (medical certificate, incident report)
Cambridge reviews and may grant 1-5% mark adjustment or allow re-sit without fee in exceptional cases
Decision final and not subject to appeal
Candidate/parents informed of outcome with results release

content.title: What Special Consideration Does NOT Cover
items: Long-term illness known before exam (should have applied for access arrangements)
Minor ailments (slight cold, headache) unless accompanied by medical evidence
Misreading timetable or arriving late due to candidate error
Lack of preparation or revision
Bereavement of distant relatives or friends
Personal choices (staying up late before exam, not eating breakfast)

content.title: Evidence Requirements
items: Medical certificates must be on official letterhead, dated, signed by doctor/psychologist
Specify: nature of condition, dates affected, impact on exam performance
School counselor reports for psychological/emotional issues
Incident reports for Centre-level disturbances (completed by Exams Officer)
Retain all documentation for 5 years for audit purposes

content.text: Cambridge defines malpractice as any act that compromises the integrity, security, or reputation of examinations. Both candidates and Centre staff can commit malpractice. Penalties range from warnings to permanent disqualification or Centre suspension.

content.title: Types of Candidate Malpractice
rows: Submitting work copied from internet, books, or other students without citation. Common in coursework-based subjects.
Working with others on individually-assigned tasks or sharing answers during exam.
Someone else taking exam on candidate's behalf, or candidate taking exam for another.
Bringing notes, phones, smartwatches, or prohibited calculators into exam room.
Refusing to follow instructions, verbal abuse toward invigilators, intentional noise/disturbance.
Talking, passing notes, or signaling to other candidates during exam.
Using approved accommodations improperly (e.g., reader providing answers instead of reading questions).

content.title: Types of Centre Malpractice
rows: Opening exam packets before Key Time, inadequate secure storage, allowing unauthorized access.
Giving candidates extra time without approval, incorrect exam papers distributed, timing errors.
Not reporting suspected candidate malpractice or irregularities to Cambridge.
Teachers providing hints, explaining questions, or editing student work during exams.
Fraudulent medical certificates for special consideration, false attendance records.

content.title: Prevention Strategies
items: Annual invigilator training emphasizing malpractice recognition and reporting obligations
Clear communication to students: exam rules, consequences of malpractice, academic integrity expectations
Seating arrangements: sufficient spacing, staggered entry/exit to minimize copying opportunities
Vigilant invigilation: regular movement, observation of candidate behavior, checking desks and materials
Secure material handling: strict adherence to Key Times, access controls, audit trails
Plagiarism detection: Use Turnitin or similar software for coursework submissions
Anonymous reporting mechanism for students to report suspected cheating

content.title: Detection and Response During Exam
items: Invigilator observes suspected malpractice (candidate using phone, copying from another, unauthorized notes)
Discreetly confiscate evidence without disrupting other candidates or alerting suspected candidate excessively
Allow candidate to complete exam under increased supervision (do NOT remove candidate unless severe disruption)
After exam, invigilator completes detailed Malpractice Report Form: what, when, who, evidence collected
Exams Officer interviews candidate and invigilator separately to gather facts
Centre Head reviews report and evidence, decides whether to submit to Cambridge

content.title: Reporting to Cambridge
items: ALL suspected malpractice MUST be reported to Cambridge within 7 days via Cambridge International Direct
Upload: completed Malpractice Report Form, candidate statement (if obtained), photographs of evidence, witness statements
Cambridge Malpractice Team investigates: reviews evidence, may request additional information or conduct interviews
Decision typically within 4-6 weeks: No Case to Answer, Warning, Mark Deduction, Disqualification from subject, Disqualification from all subjects, Ban from future exams
Centre and candidate notified in writing; decision may be appealed within 14 days if new evidence emerges
Penalties applied before results release if malpractice confirmed

content.title: Malpractice Penalties
rows: First-time minor offence. Recorded but no mark penalty. Future offences treated more severely.
5-20% deduction from affected component. Applied for minor plagiarism, unauthorized material possession.
Zero marks for specific paper/component. Applied for significant copying, collusion.
Zero marks for entire subject. Applied for serious offences like impersonation, extensive plagiarism.
All subjects in that exam series voided. Applied for systematic cheating, Centre-wide collusion.
Prohibited from Cambridge exams for 1-3 years or permanently. Applied for repeat offenders, very serious breaches.

content.title: Centre Malpractice Sanctions
content.text: If Centre found responsible for malpractice (security breach, misadministration), Cambridge may: issue formal warning, require additional training, conduct unannounced Centre inspections, suspend Centre registration (preventing future exam administration), or revoke Centre status permanently. Centre costs for re-inspections borne by Centre.

content.title: Preventing Plagiarism in Coursework
items: Teach academic integrity explicitly: citation skills, paraphrasing, when to quote
Require interim submissions: drafts, research notes, bibliography to verify originality
Use Turnitin or similar plagiarism detection software for all coursework before submission to Cambridge
Provide clear task guidelines: word limits, required sources, formatting expectations
Authenticate authorship: discussions with student about their work, check against in-class writing samples
Educate on consequences: share Cambridge malpractice penalties, real case examples

content.title: Student Education on Malpractice
items: Annual assembly presentation on exam integrity, malpractice definitions, and consequences
Written Candidate Agreement signed by students and parents acknowledging rules
Display posters in exam rooms: 'Malpractice = Disqualification'
Include academic integrity module in study skills curriculum
Remind students before each exam: no phones, no unauthorized materials, no communication

content.text: After candidates complete exams, scripts must be securely collected, packaged, and dispatched to Cambridge examiners within strict deadlines. Two marking methods: Paper-Based (physical scripts mailed) and e-Assessment (scripts scanned and uploaded).

content.title: Script Collection Process (Immediately After Exam)
items: Invigilators collect all scripts, additional answer sheets, and rough work in candidate number order
Count scripts and verify total matches attendance register
Check each script has: candidate name, candidate number, Centre number, subject code clearly written
Place scripts in secure envelope provided by Cambridge, seal immediately
Complete Dispatch Cover Sheet: Centre number, subject, component, number of scripts, date
Exams Officer receives sealed envelope and stores in secure cabinet until dispatch

content.title: Paper-Based Marking (Traditional Method)
content.text: Scripts physically mailed to Cambridge-approved examiners. Used for subjects with diagrams, maps, artwork, or extended writing where digital scanning may lose quality.

content.title: Packaging Scripts for Dispatch
items: Group scripts by subject and component (e.g., all Mathematics Paper 2 Extended scripts together)
Place in Cambridge-provided envelopes or approved courier packaging
Affix address labels: Cambridge examiners' addresses provided via Cambridge International Direct
Include Dispatch Cover Sheet listing: Centre details, subject/component codes, number of scripts, examiner code
Seal securely with tamper-evident tape
Weigh packages and arrange courier pickup (DHL, FedEx, or Cambridge-approved courier)

content.title: Dispatch Deadlines (Critical)
items: Scripts MUST be dispatched within 2 working days of exam completion
Use tracked courier service (not regular post) to ensure delivery proof
Retain tracking numbers and photograph packages before dispatch
Late dispatch may result in Centre penalty or candidate results delay
If courier delay expected (public holidays, customs), notify Cambridge immediately via Support Hub

content.title: e-Assessment (Electronic Marking)
content.text: Increasingly common for subjects like English, Mathematics, Sciences. Candidates write on paper; Centre scans scripts and uploads to Cambridge secure portal. Examiners mark online with digital annotation tools.

content.title: e-Assessment Process
items: Candidates write answers on pre-printed e-Assessment booklets with barcodes
After exam, Exams Officer uses high-quality scanner (minimum 200 DPI, grayscale) to scan all pages
Verify scan quality: text legible, no pages missing, barcodes readable
Upload scanned PDFs to Cambridge e-Assessment portal via Cambridge International Direct
Portal validates uploads (checks barcodes, page counts, file sizes)
Receive confirmation receipt; retain physical scripts for 3 months in case rescanning needed
Upload deadline: typically 3 working days after exam (check subject-specific guidance)

content.title: e-Assessment Technical Requirements
items: Scanner: Flatbed or sheet-feed, 200+ DPI resolution, grayscale mode
Internet: Stable connection for uploads (large files, 50-200 MB per subject)
Software: Cambridge-provided scanning utility or compatible PDF creation software
Training: Exams Officer completes Cambridge e-Assessment training module annually
Backup: If upload fails repeatedly, physical script dispatch available as contingency

content.title: Handling Missing or Damaged Scripts
items: If script goes missing: Report to Cambridge within 24 hours via urgent Support Hub ticket
Provide: candidate details, circumstances of loss, whether candidate completed exam
Cambridge may accept: scanned copy if available, special consideration application, or allow re-sit
Damaged scripts (water damage, torn pages): Scan/photograph damage, notify Cambridge, dispatch as normal with explanation
Centre liable for unexplained script loss; may face investigation and sanctions

content.title: Record Keeping
items: Maintain Script Dispatch Log: date dispatched, tracking numbers, recipient, script counts
Retain courier receipts and tracking confirmations for 5 years
Save upload confirmation emails for e-Assessment subjects
Archive Dispatch Cover Sheets and attendance registers
Audit trail essential for Cambridge inspections and dispute resolution

content.text: Cambridge releases exam results approximately 8-12 weeks after exam completion. Centres receive results electronically; printed certificates mailed later. Post-results services available for candidates seeking grade reviews.

content.title: Results Day Process
items: Exams Officer logs into Cambridge International Direct at 6:00 AM UK time on results day
Download Provisional Results Report (PDF and Excel): lists all candidates with grades, marks, component breakdowns
Verify data accuracy: check candidate names, subjects, grade anomalies
Print individual Candidate Results Slips (Statement of Results) for each student
Organize Results Collection: schedule (e.g., 10:00 AM onwards), require student ID for collection, notify parents of availability
Celebrate achievements: recognize high performers, support those needing re-sits or grade reviews

content.title: Cambridge Grading Scale
rows: A* (highest), A, B, C, D, E, F, G, U (ungraded)
a, b, c, d, e (lowercase), U (ungraded)
A* (highest), A, B, C, D, E, U (ungraded)

content.title: Understanding Results Slips
content.text: Each Candidate Statement of Results shows: candidate name and number, Centre number, subject title and code, grade achieved, component marks and totals, series (e.g., June 2025). Does NOT show: percentages, grade boundaries, examiner comments (unless specifically requested via post-results services).

content.title: Certificates (Issued 2-3 Months After Results)
content.text: Official Cambridge certificates printed on security paper mailed to Centre. Typically arrive October-November (for June series) or March-April (for November series). Certificates show: candidate full name (as registered), Centre name and number, subject title, grade achieved, examination series, unique certificate number.

content.title: Certificate Distribution and Retention
items: Exams Officer verifies certificate accuracy upon receipt: names spelled correctly, grades match results slips
Organize certificate collection ceremony or mail to graduates
Require signature upon collection for accountability
Uncollected certificates stored securely for minimum 1 year, then available upon request indefinitely
Lost certificates: candidates may request replacements from Cambridge (fee applies, 4-6 weeks processing)

content.title: Post-Results Services (EARs: Enquiries About Results)
content.text: If candidate or school believes result inaccurate, may request Cambridge re-check marking. Three service types available, each with fees and deadlines.

content.title: EAR Service Types
rows: Verify marks added correctly, all pages marked, no scoring errors. Grade rarely changes. Fee: ~USD 20-30 per component.
Senior examiner re-marks script. Grade may increase, decrease, or stay same. Fee: ~USD 50-80 per component.
Purchase copy of marked script to see examiner comments/marks. Does NOT include re-mark. Fee: ~USD 15-25 per component.

content.title: Submitting EAR Requests
items: Deadline: 4-6 weeks after results release (exact date provided with results); late requests not accepted
Exams Officer submits via Cambridge International Direct: select candidates, components, service type
Payment: Centre pays upfront (typically passes cost to students/parents); refund if grade increases
Consent: Candidate must sign EAR Consent Form acknowledging grade may decrease (rare but possible)
Processing time: Clerical re-check 2-3 weeks, Review of Marking 4-6 weeks
Outcome: Cambridge notifies Centre of result (grade changed or confirmed); updated certificates issued if grade changes

content.title: When to Consider EAR
items: Grade significantly lower than predicted based on mocks, coursework, teacher assessment
Candidate 1-2 marks from next grade boundary (use 'Access to Scripts' to verify before costly re-mark)
Component mark anomaly: one paper very low compared to others in same subject
University offer conditional on specific grade (e.g., needs B, received C)
NOT recommended: fishing expeditions hoping for lucky upgrade, grades consistent with student ability

content.title: Re-Sits
content.text: Candidates may re-take any exam to improve grades. No limit on attempts. Register for next available series (October/November or May/June). New result replaces previous on certificate only if higher; both results visible on full transcript. Universities typically accept re-sit grades but may prefer first-attempt results for competitive programs.

content.title: Transcript Requests
items: Candidates may request official Transcripts (cumulative record of all Cambridge exams taken) for university applications
Submit via Cambridge International Direct or request form; fee applies (USD 20-30 per transcript)
Delivered to universities directly (not to candidate) to ensure authenticity
Processing 2-3 weeks; rush service available for urgent deadlines

content.text: For subjects with coursework components (projects, portfolios, speaking tests, practical assessments), teachers assess student work using Cambridge mark schemes. Internal moderation ensures consistency and accuracy before submitting marks to Cambridge for external moderation.

content.title: Common Coursework Subjects
rows: Portfolio (50-60% of grade): sustained project + final outcome
Practical assignments (60%): document production, databases, presentations
Speaking Test (30%): conversation and discussion, marked by teacher
Design Project (50%): investigation, design, make, evaluate
Practical Skills (20%): lab work, data analysis, evaluation

content.title: Teacher Assessment Process
items: Teacher assigns coursework tasks aligned with Cambridge syllabus requirements (mark schemes, assessment criteria provided by Cambridge)
Students complete work over several weeks/months with interim feedback (formative, not summative)
Teacher marks completed work using Cambridge mark scheme: criterion-referenced (not norm-referenced), awarding marks for specific skill demonstrations
Record marks on Candidate Record Sheets with brief justification notes
Retain all student work and teacher annotations for internal moderation and Cambridge external moderation

content.title: Internal Moderation (Within Centre)
items: Purpose: Ensure all teachers in subject department apply mark schemes consistently, especially if multiple teachers teach same subject
Timing: After teachers complete initial marking, before submitting marks to Cambridge (typically 2-3 weeks before deadline)
Process: Subject Leader (or Principal) reviews sample of student work from each teacher representing range of achievement (high, middle, low)
Standardization Meeting: Teachers discuss marking decisions, compare interpretations of criteria, agree on consistent standards
Adjustments: If discrepancies found (e.g., Teacher A marks more leniently than Teacher B), re-mark affected student work to align
Documentation: Complete Internal Moderation Form summarizing process, adjustments made, final marks

content.title: Submitting Coursework Marks to Cambridge
items: Deadline: Typically 2-3 months before exam series starts (check Cambridge calendar for specific dates)
Submit via Cambridge International Direct: enter marks for each candidate, upload sample of student work
Sample size: Cambridge specifies (e.g., 8-10 candidates representing range of marks), highest, lowest, grade boundaries
Upload requirements: Digital files (PDFs, images, videos depending on subject) or mail physical work (artwork, models)
Centre retains all student work until after results released in case Cambridge requests additional samples

content.title: External Moderation by Cambridge
content.text: Cambridge-appointed moderators review submitted samples to verify Centre's marking accuracy. Three possible outcomes: Accepted (marks confirmed), Adjusted Upward (Centre marked too harshly), Adjusted Downward (Centre marked too leniently). Adjustments apply proportionally to all candidates' marks, not just sample.

content.title: Moderation Outcomes
rows: Centre marking judged accurate. No changes. Most common outcome for experienced Centres.
Centre marked harshly. All marks scaled up by fixed percentage or points. Final grades may improve.
Centre marked leniently. All marks scaled down. Final grades may decrease. Requires teacher re-training.

content.title: Standardization Meetings (Annual)
items: Held at start of academic year before coursework begins
All teachers of coursework subjects attend
Review Cambridge mark schemes, assessment criteria updates, examiner reports from previous year
Practice marking: Teachers independently mark sample work (provided by Cambridge or from previous year), compare marks, discuss discrepancies
Agree on departmental standards: interpretation of criteria, common misconceptions, evidence requirements
Document agreed standards in Subject Handbook for reference throughout year

content.title: Best Practices for Coursework Quality
items: Provide clear task briefs to students: criteria, word/time limits, deadlines, submission format
Authenticate authorship: require interim drafts, witness statements for practical work, plagiarism checks
Annotate student work: highlight where marks awarded, note strengths/weaknesses against criteria
Avoid over-teaching: do NOT give specific answers, rewrite student work, or provide excessive scaffolding that compromises independence
Use past coursework examples (anonymized) to show students standards expected
Archive exemplar work at each grade level for future reference and standardization

content.title: Common Moderation Issues to Avoid
items: Leniency: Awarding marks for potential rather than actual evidence demonstrated
Severity: Expecting perfection; not recognizing good-enough performance for mark band
Inconsistency: Different standards for different students/classes
Misinterpretation: Focusing on wrong criteria (e.g., quantity over quality, presentation over content)
Insufficient Evidence: Marks not justified by documented work
Late Submission: Missing Cambridge deadlines delays results

content.text: Cambridge offers extensive professional development (PD) programs to support teachers delivering Cambridge curriculum. PD includes online courses, face-to-face workshops, webinars, and teaching resources. Eduversal Partner Schools prioritize Cambridge PD as core component of teacher development.

content.title: Cambridge Professional Development Qualifications
rows: Entry-level, 40-60 hours online. Covers teaching, learning, assessment basics. Suitable for new Cambridge teachers.
Cambridge International Certificate in Teaching and Learning
Intermediate, 120-150 hours. Classroom-based research, reflective practice. For experienced teachers.
Cambridge International Diploma in Teaching and Learning
Advanced, 200+ hours. Leadership, curriculum development, mentoring. For Subject Leaders/Coordinators.

content.title: Accessing Cambridge PD
items: Centres access PD via Cambridge Professional Development website (https://professionaldevelopment.cambridge.org)
Quality Nominee or Principal registers Centre and teachers using Centre number
Select courses: subject-specific (e.g., IGCSE Mathematics Teaching), skills-based (e.g., Assessment for Learning), role-based (e.g., Exams Officer Training)
Enrollment: Some courses free for Cambridge Centres; others fee-based (USD 100-500 depending on qualification level)
Completion: Teachers work through modules at own pace (online courses) or attend scheduled workshops (face-to-face)
Certification: Upon completion, receive Cambridge PD Certificate (add to professional portfolio, recognized globally)

content.title: Key PD Topics for Eduversal Teachers
items: Introduction to Cambridge Curriculum: Structure, philosophy, learner attributes
Active Learning Strategies: Inquiry-based teaching, student-centered methods
Assessment for Learning: Formative assessment, feedback techniques, differentiation
Exam Preparation: Mark scheme interpretation, past paper usage, exam technique coaching
Coursework Moderation: Internal standardization, mark scheme application, avoiding malpractice
Digital Teaching: Cambridge LMS (Learning Management System), online resources, blended learning
Inclusive Education: Supporting diverse learners, access arrangements, differentiation

content.title: Cambridge Resource Portals
content.text: Cambridge provides teachers with comprehensive online resources accessible via Cambridge International Direct and subject-specific portals.

content.title: Available Resources
items: Syllabuses and Specimen Papers: Official curriculum documents, assessment objectives, sample exams
Past Exam Papers and Mark Schemes: 3-5 years of previous exams with answers, examiner comments
Schemes of Work: Suggested lesson sequences, learning objectives, teaching activities (adaptable to local context)
Endorsed Textbooks: Cambridge-approved textbooks listed by subject (schools purchase separately)
Teacher Guides: Subject-specific pedagogy, common student misconceptions, differentiation strategies
Examiner Reports: Annual feedback on student performance, common errors, areas for improvement
Resource Plus: Multimedia teaching materials (videos, simulations, worksheets) for selected subjects

content.title: Using Past Papers Effectively
items: Do NOT teach past papers as curriculum; use for assessment practice after content taught
Analyze mark schemes: understand how examiners award marks (keywords, required steps, alternative answers)
Use examiner reports: identify common errors from previous years, teach explicitly to avoid
Stagger practice: early in course use questions by topic; closer to exams use full timed papers
Model exam technique: demonstrate reading questions carefully, time management, showing working
Review mistakes: students analyze errors, identify misconceptions, redo corrections

content.title: Cambridge Webinars and Online Events
content.text: Cambridge regularly hosts free webinars for teachers on curriculum updates, exam changes, teaching strategies. Announced via Cambridge email newsletters and website. Typically 60-90 minutes, recorded and available for later viewing. Eduversal encourages teachers to attend at least 2-3 webinars per year relevant to subjects taught.

content.title: Face-to-Face Workshops (Regional)
items: Cambridge organizes regional workshops in major Indonesian cities (Jakarta, Surabaya, Bali) 2-3 times per year
Topics: New syllabus introductions, exam officer training, subject-specific deep dives
Duration: Typically 1-2 days; fees apply (USD 200-400 including materials)
Networking: Opportunity to meet teachers from other Cambridge schools, share practices
Eduversal supports teacher attendance: covers fees, travel, accommodation for relevant workshops

content.title: Integrating Cambridge PD into School Development
items: Annual PD Needs Analysis: Subject Leaders identify gaps in teacher knowledge/skills based on student performance, exam reports
Personalized PD Plans: Each teacher has annual PD plan including minimum 1 Cambridge qualification or 3+ webinars
PD Tracking: Principal monitors completion via Cambridge PD portal, discusses application in appraisal meetings
Sharing Practice: Teachers who complete PD courses lead department workshops sharing key takeaways
Budget Allocation: School budgets 2-3% of revenue for PD fees, workshop attendance, resource subscriptions
Recognition: Celebrate PD achievements in staff meetings, include in promotion criteria

content.title: Mandatory PD for Key Roles
items: New Cambridge Teachers: Complete Cambridge PDQ within first year
Exams Officers: Attend Cambridge Exams Officer Training (online course) every 3 years
Subject Leaders: Cambridge International Certificate or Diploma within 2 years of appointment
Quality Nominee: Attend Cambridge Quality Management workshops when offered
Coursework Teachers: Complete subject-specific moderation training before first cohort

content.text: The Cambridge International School Award recognizes schools demonstrating excellence in delivering Cambridge curriculum beyond basic compliance. Voluntary accreditation celebrating innovation, professional development, and international engagement. Valid for 3 years, renewable.

content.title: Award Levels
rows: Entry level: minimum standards met across 5 areas. Suitable for schools new to Cambridge (1-2 years).
Established Cambridge delivery: strong teaching, student support, professional development.
Exemplary practice: innovation, leadership, international collaboration, outstanding outcomes.

content.title: Five Areas of Assessment
items: Curriculum: Breadth and depth of Cambridge subjects offered, alignment with school's educational philosophy
Teaching and Learning: Active learning strategies, differentiation, use of Cambridge resources
Professional Development: Teacher participation in Cambridge PD, internal training, knowledge sharing
Student Support: Academic counseling, exam preparation, university guidance, wellbeing services
International Dimension: Global perspectives integrated in curriculum, international partnerships, cultural exchange programs

content.title: Application Process
items: Eligibility: Centre operational minimum 1 year with at least one exam series completed
Expression of Interest: Quality Nominee submits online form via Cambridge International website indicating interest and target level
Self-Assessment: Complete detailed questionnaire (20-30 pages) documenting evidence for each of five areas
Evidence Portfolio: Compile supporting documents (PD certificates, lesson plans, student work samples, partnership agreements, exam results analysis)
Submission: Upload questionnaire and portfolio via Cambridge portal; no application fee
Review: Cambridge Award Team reviews submission (4-6 weeks); may request clarification or additional evidence
Site Visit (Advanced Level only): Cambridge representative visits Centre for 1-2 days to observe teaching, interview staff/students, verify evidence
Decision: Award granted or areas for improvement identified; valid 3 years from grant date

content.title: Benefits of Award
items: Recognition: Use Cambridge International School Award logo on website, marketing materials, letterhead
Prestige: Distinguish school from competitors; attract high-quality students and teachers
Marketing: Feature in Cambridge's online directory of award-winning schools
Networking: Access exclusive events, conferences, online community for award holders
Quality Assurance: External validation of school's educational quality beyond basic compliance
Continuous Improvement: Framework for school self-evaluation and development planning

content.title: Foundation Level Focus (Entry Point for Eduversal Schools)
content.text: Most Eduversal Partner Schools target Foundation Level initially, progressing to Intermediate within 3-5 years. Foundation criteria manageable for schools with strong operational systems already in place.

content.title: Foundation Level Requirements (Summary)
items: Curriculum: Offer minimum 5 Cambridge subjects; clear schemes of work aligned to syllabuses
Teaching: Evidence of active learning in 50%+ lessons; differentiation for diverse learners
PD: 60% of Cambridge teachers completed at least 1 Cambridge PD course in past 3 years
Student Support: Dedicated academic counseling; exam preparation programs; track student destinations
International Dimension: Participate in minimum 1 international project/partnership; teach global perspectives

content.title: Preparation Timeline (Recommended)
items: Month 1-2: Form Award Working Group (Quality Nominee, Principal, 2-3 teachers); review criteria and self-assess gaps
Month 3-6: Address gaps (launch PD campaign, formalize student support structures, document existing practices)
Month 7-9: Compile evidence portfolio (collect artifacts, photograph displays, record testimonials)
Month 10-11: Complete self-assessment questionnaire; internal review by SLT for accuracy
Month 12: Submit application; await Cambridge feedback
Realistic timeline: 12-18 months from decision to apply to receiving award

content.title: Renewal Process (Every 3 Years)
items: Cambridge notifies Centres 6 months before expiry
Submit updated self-assessment highlighting improvements since last award
Demonstrate sustained commitment to five areas (not starting from scratch)
Review faster than initial application (2-3 weeks)
Opportunity to upgrade to next level (Foundation  Intermediate  Advanced)

content.title: Eduversal Network Goal
content.text: Eduversal aims for all Partner Schools to achieve minimum Foundation Level Cambridge International School Award within 3 years of Cambridge Centre registration. Advanced Level schools designated as Flagship Schools within network, tasked with mentoring newer Partner Schools.

All Cambridge Centres must comply with Cambridge Assessment International Education policies governing curriculum delivery, examination administration, safeguarding, and data protection. Non-compliance may result in warnings, sanctions, or Centre registration suspension.

content.title: Core Cambridge Policies (Mandatory Reading for All Staff)
items: Cambridge Handbook for Centres: Comprehensive guide covering all Centre responsibilities (updated annually, ~200 pages)
Regulations for Cambridge Schools: Legal framework, Centre registration requirements, compliance obligations
Instructions for Conducting Examinations (ICE): Detailed procedures for exam administration, invigilation, security
Preventing and Detecting Malpractice: Definitions, reporting procedures, sanctions
Data Protection and Confidentiality Policy: Handling candidate data, exam materials, results
Safeguarding Policy: Child protection, safe recruitment, reporting concerns
Access Arrangements and Special Considerations Policy: Procedures for supporting candidates with additional needs

content.title: Ensuring Policy Compliance
items: Annual Policy Review: Quality Nominee downloads latest versions of all policies from Cambridge website (August-September)
Staff Training: Induction for new staff covering key policies; annual refresher for all staff (October)
Policy Register: Maintain internal document tracking policy names, versions, distribution, staff sign-off confirming they've read and understood
Accessibility: Store policies in shared staff drive; print copies in staff room; include summaries in Staff Handbook
Monitoring: Principal conducts spot checks (e.g., observing exams, reviewing coursework marking) to verify adherence
Incident Reporting: Clear process for staff to report policy breaches or uncertainties (escalate to Quality Nominee)

content.title: Annual Compliance Checklist (By Quarter)
rows: Policy review and staff training; Annual Centre Declaration submitted; Secure storage audit; Exams Officer appointed/confirmed
Exam entries submitted (May/June series); Access arrangements applications processed; Coursework moderation plans finalized
Mock exams conducted; Invigilator training refresher; Exam room setup inspected; Secure materials received and verified
Exams administered per ICE guidelines; Scripts dispatched on time; Malpractice reports submitted if applicable; Post-exam debrief and lessons learned

content.title: Annual Centre Declaration
content.text: Every February-March, Cambridge requires each Centre to submit Annual Centre Declaration confirming: contact details current, key personnel (Centre Head, Exams Officer, Quality Nominee) updated, adequate facilities for secure exam administration, commitment to Cambridge standards and policies. Deadline typically mid-March; non-submission blocks exam entries for next series.

content.title: Completing Annual Declaration
items: Cambridge emails Centre Head and Quality Nominee with declaration link (February)
Quality Nominee logs into Cambridge International Direct, accesses Declaration form
Update Centre information: address, phone, email, website, key staff names and contact details
Confirm statements: 'We have adequate secure storage,' 'Staff trained on Cambridge policies,' 'We comply with malpractice reporting,' etc.
Centre Head reviews and electronically signs declaration (binding legal commitment)
Submit by deadline; receive confirmation email; print copy for Centre records
Failure to submit: Cambridge freezes Centre account, preventing exam entries and material dispatch

content.title: Key Policy Areas Requiring Continuous Attention
items: Secure Storage: Regular audits of cabinet locks, access logs, CCTV functionality (if installed)
Confidentiality: No unauthorized disclosure of exam content, candidate results, or Centre performance data
Conflict of Interest: Staff with family members taking exams must declare; may be excluded from invigilation or marking
Intellectual Property: Do not photocopy or distribute Cambridge copyrighted materials (past papers, mark schemes) beyond internal use
Complaints Handling: Follow Cambridge's complaints procedure for candidate/parent grievances about Centre exam administration
Record Retention: Maintain exam records (attendance registers, dispatch logs, incident reports) for minimum 5 years

content.title: Responding to Policy Updates
content.text: Cambridge issues policy updates irregularly (typically 1-2 per year). Communicated via email to Centre Head and Quality Nominee. Updates may include: new regulations (e.g., calculator restrictions), clarifications on existing policies, deadline changes, procedural improvements.

content.title: Policy Update Protocol
items: Quality Nominee receives Cambridge email announcement; reviews changes and impact on Centre operations
Assess urgency: immediate action (e.g., exam security alert) vs. plan for implementation (e.g., next year's syllabuses)
Communicate to affected staff: email summary, discuss in SLT meeting, update Staff Handbook
Revise Centre procedures if needed: update exam protocols, training materials, checklists
Document changes in Policy Register with effective date
Confirm understanding: staff sign acknowledgment of updated policy

content.title: Common Compliance Pitfalls to Avoid
items: Assuming policies unchanged: Always verify latest version annually; Cambridge updates regularly
Inadequate staff training: Don't rely solely on written policies; conduct interactive training with scenarios
Poor documentation: If not written down, didn't happen; maintain audit trails for all compliance activities
Delayed reporting: Malpractice, security breaches, irregularities MUST be reported within Cambridge-specified timeframes (usually 7 days)
Informal arrangements: E.g., verbal agreements on access arrangements not recognized; everything must be formally documented and approved
Neglecting small non-compliances: Minor breaches (e.g., opening packet 5 minutes early) can escalate if pattern emerges

content.text: Cambridge conducts Centre inspections to verify compliance with policies, assess examination security, and support quality improvement. Inspections may be routine (scheduled) or triggered (unannounced following concerns). Centres must cooperate fully; refusal may result in suspension.

content.title: Types of Cambridge Visits
rows: For new Centre applications. Verify facilities, staffing, commitment to standards. Scheduled with Centre. Determines approval.
Periodic (every 5-7 years) for established Centres in good standing. Scheduled 4-6 weeks in advance. Focus on continuous improvement.
During exam series. Verify secure storage, invigilation practices, script handling. May be announced or unannounced.
Following malpractice report, persistent irregularities, or candidate complaints. Usually unannounced. Forensic focus.
By request from Centre seeking guidance on complex issues (e.g., setting up e-Assessment). Consultative, not evaluative.

content.title: Inspection Focus Areas
items: Secure Storage: Physical security of exam room, cabinet/safe condition, access controls, audit logs
Exam Administration: Invigilation procedures, room setup, Key Time adherence, script collection
Record Keeping: Attendance registers, dispatch logs, malpractice reports, access arrangement documentation
Staff Qualifications: Invigilator training records, Exams Officer competency, Quality Nominee engagement
Policy Compliance: Evidence of staff training, policy dissemination, incident response protocols
Student Experience: Candidate feedback, exam conditions (comfort, fairness), support services
Coursework Moderation: Internal standardization processes, mark scheme application, work authentication

content.title: Routine Visit Process (Scheduled)
items: Notification: Cambridge emails Centre 4-6 weeks in advance with visit dates and focus areas
Pre-Visit Questionnaire: Centre completes self-assessment covering operations, challenges, recent changes
Logistics: Centre arranges meeting room, access to storage areas, staff availability, lunch for inspector(s)
Visit Day 1: Opening meeting with SLT, tour of facilities, review of documentation, observation of exam (if during series)
Visit Day 2: Interviews with Exams Officer, teachers, students; deep dive into specific areas (e.g., coursework); feedback session
Report: Cambridge issues written report (2-3 weeks post-visit) with commendations, recommendations, required actions
Action Plan: Centre develops response addressing recommendations; submit to Cambridge within 4 weeks
Follow-Up: Cambridge monitors implementation; may conduct follow-up visit if serious concerns identified

content.title: Exam Security Inspection (Unannounced)
items: Inspector arrives without prior notice during exam series
Verify secure storage: Check locks, access logs, CCTV (if applicable), packet integrity
Observe exam in progress: Invigilation quality, room setup, candidate conduct, emergency procedures
Review Key Time compliance: Verify packets opened only at authorized times; no premature access
Inspect script handling: Collection, counting, secure storage until dispatch
Interview Exams Officer: Understanding of procedures, handling of irregularities, communication with Cambridge
Immediate feedback: Inspector highlights any urgent concerns requiring immediate remediation
Formal report: Issued within 1 week if serious breaches found; may impose sanctions or require corrective action

content.title: Possible Inspection Outcomes
rows: No significant issues. Centre meets all standards. Next routine visit in 5-7 years.
Minor issues identified. Recommendations for improvement. Action plan required. Follow-up within 1 year.
Serious breaches (security, malpractice, inadequate facilities). Immediate action plan required. Possible Centre sanctions. Follow-up visit within 3-6 months.
Critical failures threatening exam integrity. Centre registration suspended pending remediation. No exams until reinstated.

content.title: Preparing for Inspection (Proactive Approach)
items: Maintain readiness: Assume inspection could occur anytime; don't wait for notification
Regular self-audits: Quality Nominee conducts quarterly checks using Cambridge's inspection criteria
Documentation current: Keep all records up-to-date, organized, easily accessible (physical and digital backups)
Staff briefing: All staff aware of procedures; can articulate roles and responsibilities if interviewed
Mock inspections: Annually, invite external reviewer (from partner school or Eduversal QMS team) to conduct practice inspection
Address issues promptly: Don't defer problems hoping they won't be noticed; proactive remediation shows commitment
Evidence portfolio: Compile examples of good practice (lesson observations, student work, PD certificates) to showcase strengths

content.title: Common Inspection Findings (Areas for Improvement)
items: Secure storage: Locks not functioning properly, access logs incomplete, unauthorized personnel present
Invigilator training: Records missing, training superficial, staff unable to explain malpractice procedures
Key Time breaches: Packets opened early for 'preparation,' unauthorized personnel handle materials
Script dispatch delays: Scripts not dispatched within 2-day deadline, no tracking documentation
Record retention: Incomplete attendance registers, missing dispatch logs, inadequate malpractice documentation
Coursework authentication: Insufficient evidence of authorship verification, plagiarism checks not documented
Staff awareness: Teachers unfamiliar with Cambridge policies, unable to articulate procedures

content.title: Responding to Negative Findings
items: Acknowledge issues: Don't be defensive; accept findings and commit to improvement
Root cause analysis: Investigate why issue occurred (lack of training, resource constraints, procedural gap)
Develop action plan: Specific actions, responsible persons, deadlines, success criteria
Communicate plan to Cambridge: Submit within required timeframe (typically 4 weeks)
Implement rigorously: Allocate resources, monitor progress, document completion
Report progress: Update Cambridge at milestones; request extension if needed (with justification)
Prevent recurrence: Revise procedures, enhance training, increase monitoring to ensure lasting change
Demonstrate improvement: Invite follow-up visit to verify remediation; show commitment to excellence

content.title: Eduversal Support During Inspections
content.text: Eduversal QMS Team assists Partner Schools preparing for and responding to Cambridge inspections. Services include: pre-inspection mock audits, documentation review, action plan development, attendance during inspection (if Centre requests), post-inspection remediation support.

Eduversal Partner Schools deliver both Cambridge international curriculum and Indonesian national curriculum (Kurikulum Merdeka), meeting requirements of Indonesian Ministry of Education while preparing students for global opportunities. Integration requires careful timetabling, dual assessment, and transcript management.

content.title: Timetable Balance (Typical Weekly Allocation)
rows: 18-22 hours: English, Math, Sciences, Humanities in English
8-10 hours: PPKn, Bahasa Indonesia, Pendidikan Agama, Muatan Lokal
4-6 hours: Mathematics (bilingual), Sciences (reinforcement in Bahasa), PE, Arts
2-3 hours: Clubs, leadership, community service, Profil Pelajar Pancasila projects

content.title: Mandatory Indonesian National Subjects (Ministry Requirement)
items: PPKn (Pendidikan Pancasila dan Kewarganegaraan): Civics, values education, citizenship (minimum 2 hours/week)
Bahasa Indonesia: National language, literature, communication skills (minimum 4-6 hours/week depending on level)
Pendidikan Agama: Religious education matching student's faith (Islam, Christian, Catholic, Hindu, Buddhist, Confucian) (minimum 2-3 hours/week)
Muatan Lokal: Local content (e.g., Javanese language and culture for schools in Central Java, Balinese culture for Bali schools) (1-2 hours/week)
Sejarah Indonesia (Secondary): Indonesian history emphasizing national identity and struggle for independence (2 hours/week for Grades 10-12)

content.title: Curriculum Integration Strategies
items: Parallel Delivery: Cambridge subjects taught primarily in English; Indonesian subjects in Bahasa Indonesia; minimal content overlap to maximize curriculum coverage
Bilingual Subjects: Mathematics and Sciences taught in English for Cambridge exams; supplementary lessons in Bahasa Indonesia to meet national curriculum competencies and prepare for ANBK
Thematic Links: Where possible, coordinate units (e.g., Global Perspectives on environmental issues + PPKn on environmental citizenship; Cambridge History + Sejarah Indonesia on colonialism)
Profil Pelajar Pancasila Projects: Use Cambridge inquiry-based learning approaches for national P5 projects (cross-curricular, values-based, community-focused)
Dual Assessment: Students take both Cambridge exams (IGCSE, AS/A Level) AND fulfill Indonesian portfolio/project requirements for national transcript
Educator Collaboration: Cambridge teachers and Indonesian curriculum teachers meet termly to identify synergies, avoid duplication, support student learning

content.title: Dual Transcripts and Certificates
content.text: Graduates receive both Cambridge certificates (international recognition) and Indonesian Ijazah (national high school diploma), enabling pathways to universities in Indonesia, Asia-Pacific, Europe, North America.

content.title: Transcript Comparison
rows: International recognition. Required for UK, Australia, US, European universities. Shows subject grades (A*-U). Accepted by top Indonesian universities.
National recognition. Required for Indonesian state universities (via SNBP, SNBT). Shows GPA (0-100 scale). Includes national subject grades (PPKn, Bahasa Indonesia, Religion).

content.title: Obtaining Indonesian Ijazah for Cambridge Students
items: Complete national subject requirements throughout Grades 10-12: PPKn, Bahasa Indonesia, Religion, Muatan Lokal, Sejarah
Participate in Profil Pelajar Pancasila (P5) projects minimum 2 per year
Achieve minimum competency in ANBK (Asesmen Nasional Berbasis Komputer) administered in Grade 11
Maintain attendance minimum 90% and good conduct record
Complete portfolio assessment: Rapor Pendidikan (report cards) from all 3 years, P5 project documentation, character assessments
School Principal issues Ijazah upon graduation verification through Dapodik (national education database)
Ijazah shows: student name (exact match with national ID), school name/NPSN, completion date, subjects and grades (national curriculum), school seal and Principal signature

content.title: University Admission Pathways
items: International Universities (Cambridge route): Apply using IGCSE/A Level grades, English proficiency (Cambridge English qualifications), personal statements, recommendations. Pathways: UCAS (UK), Common App (US), direct applications (Asia-Pacific, Europe).

Indonesian State Universities (National route): Register for SNBP (merit-based selection using Ijazah grades) or SNBT (entrance exam). Cambridge grades can supplement application but Ijazah mandatory.
Top Indonesian Private Universities: Accept both Cambridge certificates and Ijazah. Many offer scholarships for A Level students with strong grades (A*-B).
Blended Pathways: Students apply to mix of international and Indonesian universities; dual credentials provide flexibility.

content.title: Challenges and Solutions
content.text: Integrating two demanding curricula presents challenges: timetable overcrowding, student stress, staff coordination, assessment overload. Eduversal Partner Schools address these through strategic planning and support systems.

content.title: Common Integration Challenges
rows: Challenge: Timetable overcrowding (students face 40+ hours weekly)
Solution: Optimize periods (some Cambridge subjects 380-min vs 460-min), integrate co-curricular into curriculum, offer intensive national subject blocks during holidays
Solution: Stagger assessments (Cambridge mocks, national portfolios), teach time management, provide counseling, limit homework to 2 hours/day
Challenge: Staff expertise (teachers qualified in one system, unfamiliar with other)
Solution: Hire bilingual educators, provide PD in both systems, pair Cambridge and national curriculum teachers for co-teaching
Solution: Design integrated assessments where possible (e.g., Cambridge coursework fulfills P5 project), use Cambridge skills (critical thinking) in national subject assessments
Solution: Explicit teaching of academic language in both English and Bahasa, glossaries, visual supports, gradual release model

content.title: Best Practices from High-Performing Partner Schools
items: Curriculum Mapping: Annual review mapping Cambridge units to Indonesian competencies; identify overlaps and gaps
Bilingual Resources: Develop glossaries, translated materials, code-switching strategies for Math/Science
Parent Communication: Clarify dual curriculum value proposition in admissions materials, explain pathways in parent workshops
Student Choice: In Grades 11-12, allow students to emphasize Cambridge (for international universities) or balance (for Indonesian universities) based on goals
National Subject Excellence: Treat PPKn, Bahasa Indonesia, Religion as core academic subjects with same rigor as Cambridge; avoid relegating to 'compliance' status
Celebrate Both: Recognize achievements in both systems (Cambridge exam results AND ANBK performance, P5 projects) equally in assemblies, reports

content.text: Maintaining comprehensive documentation is essential for Cambridge Centre compliance, inspections, accreditation reviews, and continuous improvement. Evidence organized into Compliance Portfolio demonstrates adherence to standards and facilitates audits.

content.title: Cambridge Centre Registration and Status
items: Cambridge Centre Number Certificate (original and digital copy)
Centre Registration Application and Approval Letter
Annual Centre Declaration submissions (past 5 years) with confirmation receipts
Centre contact details and key personnel records (current and historical)
Correspondence with Cambridge regarding Centre status, policy updates, facility changes
Site visit reports (if applicable) from initial registration or quality assurance visits

content.title: Examination Administration
items: Exam Entries: Entry confirmation reports for all exam series (past 5 years), student registration data, fee payment receipts
Exam Timetables: Cambridge final timetables, Centre internal timetables, seating plans, invigilation schedules
Secure Storage Audit Logs: Access logs (who, when, purpose), key holder records, photographs of secure cabinet/room, CCTV footage (if applicable)
Materials Receipts: Delivery notes for exam packets, verification checklists, discrepancy reports
Attendance Registers: Completed for every exam, signed by invigilators, showing absences and late arrivals
Script Dispatch Records: Dispatch cover sheets, courier tracking numbers, upload confirmations (e-Assessment), dispatch logs (date, destination, script counts)
Key Time Compliance: Packet opening logs, witness signatures, photographs timestamped at Key Time
Incident Reports: Any irregularities (fire alarms, candidate illness, timing errors, technical failures) documented with actions taken

content.title: Invigilation and Exam Conduct
items: Invigilator Training Records: Attendance sheets for annual training, training materials (slides, handouts), competency assessments
Invigilator Assignments: Lists showing who invigilated which exams, avoiding conflicts of interest
Instructions for Conducting Examinations (ICE): Current version accessible to all invigilators, sign-off confirming they've read it
Exam Room Setup Checklists: Completed before each exam (desk spacing, clock accuracy, display materials removed)
Candidate Briefing Materials: Exam rules posters, candidate agreements signed by students/parents
Malpractice Reports: Any suspected incidents documented, evidence (confiscated materials, photographs), Cambridge correspondence

content.title: Coursework and Internal Assessment
items: Coursework Tasks: Assignment briefs, assessment criteria, submission deadlines given to students
Student Work Samples: Physical or digital copies of coursework across range of achievement levels (high, middle, low)
Teacher Marking: Completed Candidate Record Sheets, mark justifications, annotations on student work
Internal Moderation Records: Standardization meeting minutes, sample reviews, agreed adjustments, Internal Moderation Forms
Plagiarism Checks: Turnitin reports or equivalent for all written coursework, investigation records if issues found
Coursework Submissions to Cambridge: Upload confirmations, correspondence with Cambridge moderators, moderation outcome reports
External Moderation Results: Cambridge moderator feedback, mark adjustments applied, action plans for improvement

content.title: Access Arrangements and Special Considerations
items: Access Arrangement Applications: Completed forms submitted to Cambridge, supporting documentation (psychologist/medical reports), approval letters
Implementation Records: Evidence arrangements provided (separate room logs, reader/scribe assignments, extra time calculations)
Special Consideration Submissions: Forms with detailed circumstances, supporting evidence (medical certificates, incident reports), Cambridge decisions
Student Support Files: Confidential records of students with documented needs, accommodations history, review dates

content.title: Results and Certificates
items: Results Reports: Provisional results downloads (Excel and PDF) for all exam series, component mark breakdowns
Candidate Statements of Results: Individual slips distributed to students, collection signatures
Results Analysis: Centre performance reports comparing to global benchmarks, subject trends, value-added calculations
Certificates: Originals retained for uncollected certificates, collection logs (student signatures, dates)
Certificate Replacements: Requests submitted to Cambridge, fee receipts, delivery confirmations
EAR (Enquiries About Results): EAR requests submitted, candidate consent forms, outcomes, updated certificates if grades changed
Transcripts: Copies of official transcripts issued to universities, request logs

content.title: Professional Development
items: PD Records: Certificates from Cambridge PD courses (PDQ, International Certificate/Diploma), completion dates, course titles
Webinar Attendance: Logs of Cambridge webinars attended by staff, topics, follow-up actions
Workshop Participation: Registrations and certificates from Cambridge face-to-face workshops, travel approvals
In-House Training: Agendas and attendance for Centre-led Cambridge training (e.g., annual policy review, exam procedures refresher)
PD Plans: Individual teacher PD plans including Cambridge PD goals, progress tracking, completion evidence

content.title: Quality Assurance and Continuous Improvement
items: School Improvement Plans (SIP): Annual Cambridge-specific goals, action plans, progress monitoring, achievement evidence
Cambridge International School Award: Application, self-assessment questionnaire, evidence portfolio, award certificate (if achieved), renewal documentation
Inspection Reports: Cambridge Centre inspection reports, action plans responding to recommendations, follow-up correspondence
Self-Audit Reports: Internal compliance checks conducted by Quality Nominee, findings, corrective actions
Stakeholder Feedback: Student/parent surveys on exam administration, teacher feedback on Cambridge support, improvement initiatives
Performance Data: Cambridge exam results trends (5-year), subject performance analysis, comparisons to global averages, university admission outcomes

content.title: Policies and Procedures
items: Cambridge Policy Register: List of all applicable Cambridge policies, version numbers, effective dates, distribution records
Staff Acknowledgments: Sign-off sheets confirming staff have read and understood key Cambridge policies
Centre Procedures: Internal documents detailing how Centre implements Cambridge policies (exam day protocols, secure storage procedures, malpractice response)
Job Descriptions: Roles and responsibilities for Centre Head, Exams Officer, Quality Nominee, Subject Leaders aligned with Cambridge requirements
Complaints Records: Any formal complaints about Centre exam administration, investigation notes, resolutions, Cambridge notifications if required

content.title: Organizing the Compliance Portfolio
items: Physical Files: Secure filing cabinet in Exams Officer or Principal's office; organized by category (Exams, Coursework, PD, QA); past 5 years readily accessible
Digital Repository: Cloud storage (Google Drive, OneDrive, EduNav) with folder structure mirroring physical files; access restricted to authorized personnel
Retention Policy: Exam records minimum 5 years; coursework samples 3 years post-results; PD certificates indefinitely; policies retain current + 2 previous versions
Audit Readiness: Quarterly check by Quality Nominee to ensure all required documents present, up-to-date, properly filed; gaps addressed immediately
Backup: Digital files backed up weekly to external drive or secondary cloud location; physical files inventoried annually with critical documents scanned
Confidentiality: Student data, medical reports, malpractice investigations stored separately with restricted access per data protection requirements

content.title: Using Evidence for Continuous Improvement
content.text: Compliance Portfolio not merely for audit defense; valuable resource for reflective practice. Analyze exam results to identify teaching priorities, review incident reports for procedural improvements, study Cambridge moderator feedback to refine coursework marking. Regular portfolio review by SLT (termly) ensures evidence informs school development, not just documents compliance.

Cambridge Centre Compliance aligns with and supports multiple accreditation frameworks and regulatory systems. Understanding these connections ensures efficient compliance management and demonstrates school quality across multiple dimensions.
