categories.title: International Accreditation Standards
items: CIS (Council of International Schools) - Domain: Curriculum. Cambridge curriculum alignment demonstrates internationally recognized academic program meeting CIS's requirement for "curriculum based on international standards and best practices."
CIS - Domain: Teaching and Learning. Cambridge professional development requirements align with CIS's expectation for "ongoing professional development to support effective teaching and learning."
CIS - Domain: Assessment. Cambridge examination system and internal moderation practices fulfill CIS's standards for "valid, reliable, and fair assessment of student learning."

WASC (Western Association of Schools and Colleges) - Category B: Curriculum. Cambridge syllabuses, schemes of work, and resources demonstrate "challenging, relevant, and coherent curriculum" required by WASC.
WASC - Category C: Learning and Teaching. Cambridge pedagogy (active learning, inquiry-based, differentiation) aligns with WASC's focus on "effective instructional strategies and student engagement."
WASC - Category D: Assessment. Cambridge external exams, coursework moderation, and data analysis support WASC's requirement for "assessment systems informing instruction and improvement."

categories.title: Cambridge-Specific Requirements
items: Cambridge Handbook for Centres: Comprehensive policy document governing all Centre operations. Compliance with Handbook essential for maintaining Centre registration.

Cambridge Centre Standards: Five core standards - Governance and Management, Teaching and Learning, Student Support, Facilities and Resources, Examination Administration. Section 3 addresses all five.
Cambridge International School Award Criteria: Optional but prestigious. This section's content directly supports Foundation/Intermediate Award applications across five assessment areas.

Cambridge Safeguarding Policy: Child protection requirements overlap with Indonesian child protection laws and CIS/WASC safeguarding expectations. Integrated approach ensures comprehensive student safety.

categories.title: Indonesian National Regulations
items: UU No. 20/2003 (Sisdiknas - National Education System Law): Cambridge curriculum recognized as "international curriculum" permissible in private schools provided national subjects (PPKn, Bahasa Indonesia, Religion) delivered. Section 3.18 addresses integration.

Permendikbud No. 22/2016 (Curriculum Standards): Cambridge syllabuses fulfill "competency-based curriculum" requirement; IGCSE/A Levels demonstrate "graduate competency" at or above national standards.
Permendikbud No. 23/2016 (Assessment Standards): Cambridge examinations (external, standardized, criterion-referenced) align with Ministry's emphasis on "authentic, valid, and reliable assessment."

BAN-PDM Accreditation Standards: Cambridge Centre facilities (secure storage, exam rooms, resources) contribute to BAN-PDM's "Facilities and Infrastructure" standard. Cambridge PD supports "Educators and Personnel" standard.
Dapodik Reporting: Cambridge exam results integrated into student transcripts reported via Dapodik, fulfilling Ministry's data collection requirements for curriculum diversification tracking.

categories.title: Data Protection and Privacy
items: Indonesian PDP Law (UU No. 27/2022): Cambridge's Data Protection Policy aligns with Indonesian personal data protection requirements. Student exam data processed lawfully, securely, with consent.
GDPR Considerations (European Union): For students holding EU citizenship or planning EU university applications, Cambridge data handling GDPR-compliant, providing additional protection layer.
Cambridge Confidentiality Standards: Exam materials, candidate results, and Centre performance data treated as confidential, supporting broader school data protection policies.

categories.title: Quality Management Systems
items: Eduversal QMS: Cambridge compliance embedded in Eduversal's network-wide Quality Management System. Appraisal Domain 5 (Curriculum, Teaching, Assessment) heavily weighted toward Cambridge delivery quality.

ISO 21001 (Educational Organizations Management Systems): Cambridge's systematic approach to curriculum delivery, assessment, and continuous improvement supports ISO 21001 principles if school pursues certification.
School Improvement Planning (SIP): Cambridge exam results, moderator feedback, inspection reports provide quantitative and qualitative data for SIP goal-setting and progress monitoring.

content.title: Cross-Framework Compliance Matrix
rows: Cambridge Handbook (Section 4), CIS Safety Standards, BAN-PDM Facilities
Cambridge PD Requirements, CIS Teaching Domain, WASC Category C, Permendikbud No. 16/2007 (Teacher Standards)
Cambridge Moderation Policy, WASC Assessment Standards, BAN-PDM Assessment Standards
Cambridge Special Considerations Policy, CIS Wellbeing Standards, WASC Category E, Indonesian Child Protection Law
Cambridge Data Policy, Indonesian PDP Law, GDPR (if applicable), CIS Data Management Standards

content.title: Leveraging Cambridge Compliance for Broader Accreditation
items: Documentation Efficiency: Evidence collected for Cambridge Centre compliance (policies, PD records, exam results, student work) reusable for CIS/WASC self-studies, reducing documentation burden
Quality Indicators: Cambridge exam results provide internationally benchmarked achievement data valuable for demonstrating student learning outcomes to all accreditation bodies
Professional Credibility: Cambridge PD certifications recognized by CIS/WASC as evidence of teacher qualifications and commitment to professional growth
Curriculum Rigor: Cambridge syllabuses and examinations provide external validation of curriculum quality, addressing CIS/WASC's requirement for "evidence of program effectiveness"
Continuous Improvement: Cambridge's annual cycle (exams, results, analysis, adjustments) models continuous improvement process central to all quality frameworks
Stakeholder Confidence: Cambridge affiliation signals to parents, universities, and regulators that school meets rigorous international standards, supporting recruitment and reputation

content.title: Strategic Recommendations
items: Integrated Compliance Calendar: Align Cambridge compliance tasks (declarations, exam entries, PD) with CIS/WASC/BAN-PDM timelines to streamline workload and avoid duplication
Unified Evidence Repository: Organize Compliance Portfolio (Section 3.19) to serve multiple frameworks; tag documents by applicable standard (e.g., "CIS Domain 2, WASC Category C, Cambridge PD")
Cross-Training: Ensure Quality Nominee understands not only Cambridge requirements but also how they intersect with CIS, WASC, Indonesian regulations for holistic compliance approach

Narrative Coherence: In accreditation self-studies, articulate how Cambridge curriculum choice supports school's mission and demonstrates commitment to international excellence and Indonesian identity
Leverage Synergies: Use Cambridge exam results analysis for WASC Action Plan goals; cite Cambridge PD in CIS educator quality evidence; reference Cambridge policies in BAN-PDM documentation
Avoid Compliance Silos: Resist treating Cambridge, CIS, WASC, Indonesian regulations as separate; instead, build integrated quality system where compliance with one reinforces others

content.title: Conclusion
content.text: Cambridge Centre Compliance is not merely administrative obligation but strategic asset. Rigorous Cambridge standards elevate school operations across all domainscurriculum, teaching, assessment, student support, facilities, governance. By embedding Cambridge compliance within broader quality framework, Eduversal Partner Schools achieve efficiency, coherence, and recognition as institutions committed to excellence at local, national, and international levels.
